Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
========================================
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of HTN, HLD, 
hypothyroidism, and throat cancer who was recently hospitalized 
___ after a fall with L femoral neck fracture, underwent 
surgical fixation with post-op course complicated by new Afib, 
hematoma, and acute worsening of dysphagia, who was then 
discharged to rehab NPO, and now re-presents with fevers, 
leukocytosis, and cough in the setting of recently starting 
pureed diet. She received antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia, 
and underwent PEG tube placement. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
========================================
# Aspiration pneumonia 
Patient presented from rehab with fevers, leukocytosis, and 
cough in the setting of re-starting a pureed diet. CXR showed 
RLL consolidation. She was initially treated with vancomycin, 
ceftazidime, and Flagyl x1 dose (___), de-escalated to Unasyn 
(___), and then transitioned to Augmentin 875mg Q12H 
(start ___, END DATE ___ with plan to complete a 7-day 
course. Her WBC count on admission was 26 and subsequently 
downtrended. She remained stable and satting well on room air 
throughout the entire hospitalization. Organism was not able to 
be isolated, strep/legionella ag were negative. 

# Acute on chronic dysphagia ___ radiation from throat cancer
Patient with chronic mild dysphagia at baseline due to prior 
throat cancer s/p radiation treatment. She became acutely 
decompensated during previous hospitalization, ___ was 
placed and she was discharged on TFs, NPO. She was then 
re-started on pureed diet, with subsequent likely aspiration 
pneumonia. During last hospitalization PEG tube was discussed, 
but patient refused at that time. In light of current events, 
however, she agreed to pursue PEG tube, which was placed by ___ 
on ___. ___ tube was removed on day of discharge. 

# Anemia
Baseline Hb likely ___. During last hospitalization she had 
acute drop to 6.9, likely blood loss with hematoma formation at 
surgical site. Discharge Hb at that time was 8.1, and admission 
Hb 7.3 now, likely multifactorial but there was no evidence of 
bleeding. Her Hb downtrended to 7.0 and she received 1U pRBCs 
with appropriate bump. Work-up showed inappropriately normal 
retic, no evidence of hemolysis, iron studies consistent with 
AoCD with possible component of iron deficiency anemia (Tsat 
5%). 

CHRONIC ISSUES:
========================================
# Left femoral neck fracture
Patient had fall on ___. S/p surgical fixation. Seen by Ortho 
during this hospital stay, staples removed. 

# Atrial Fibrillation
# Bradycardia
The patient developed new atrial fibrillation during last 
hospitalization iso post-op. She was able to be converted back 
to sinus and then remained bradycardic. She was discharged on 
diltiazem and apixaban. Given persistent bradycardia to ___ 
during this admission, decision was made to discontinue 
diltiazem. Her Apixaban 5mg BID was continued. During 
hospitalization she was monitored on telemetry and noted to be 
mostly in sinus bradycardia, with periods of frequent PACs. No 
Afib with RVR. 

# HTN
Her home lisinopril 40mg QD was continued. Her systolic blood 
pressure remained elevated to 170s (diastolic ___. She was 
started on amlodipine 5mg QD. 

# HLD
Home rosuvastatin 10mg QD was continued. 

# Hypothyroidism
Home levothyroxine 50mcg QD was continued. 

# Anxiety
# Depression
Home sertraline, mirtazapine, and clonazepam were continued. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
========================================
[] PEG tube placed during this admission, continue to monitor
[] Patient had persistently elevated systolic BP with normal-low 
diastolic blood pressure. She was started on amlodipine 5mg QD 
for systolic HTN. Should continue to monitor and consider 
uptitrating amlodipine if tolerated.
